Comment: A Ruy Lopez Deferred. A deadly weapon if played right. Unfortunately, this was a bad day for me and I played it uncharacteristically bad.

Baiting d4 is a common trap in the Ruy Lopez. And sadly it's a shame how many still fall victim to its stranglehold. Hint: don't take d4!

Well. Plan A isn't working, so I work on a plan B. Create some threats of my own should a window of opportunity open.
And black castles right where I want him to go. Game on!
Now back to defensive strategy...get these pieces away from my kingside!

While developing is nice
?! - and move like this help my case (centralizing though could have waited to protect this pawn)
A free pawn is a free pawn. And one needed later.
Remember what I said about going passive? There is a time to do this. Unfortunately this isn't it.
Now the expected move is Bxd5, but instead we see this:

?? - The game ender! An unforced error. Taking the knight was the obvious move. The explanation I got from my opponent here was the following: On move 20 when I played Qh5 my thought was take on d5 next move with the bishop and win my pawn back. I have taken on d5 first and then played 21..Qh5 instead. I was looking at lines and made the move without double checking if you had a good move if I moved the queen first. Silly mistake, really. In short, ouch.
Now it's an elementary mate in 7. A great effort by an excellent opponent. Except for this mistake, the fight was truly brought to me this entire match.
